fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {E} and \mathcal {F} be topoi. A geometric morphism f\colon \mathcal {E}\to \mathcal {F} is an adjoint pair of functors
such that f^{*} is left exact. The functors f_{*} and f^{*} are called the direct image and the inverse image respectively.

Any natural transformation f_{*} \to g_{*} between the direct image part of the given geometric morphisms, f and g, corresponds to a unique natural transformation f^{*} \to g^{*} under the adjunctions f^{*} \dashv f_{*} and g^{*} \dashv g_{*}. Thus, a geometric transformation f \to g can be equivalently defined as a natural transformation f^{*} \to g^{*}.
A geometric morphism f\colon \mathcal {E}\to \mathcal {F} is said to be essential if its inverse image f^{*} admits a left adjoint.
Let f,g\colon \mathcal {E}\rightrightarrows \mathcal {F} be a pair of geometric morphisms. A geometric transformation \alpha \colon f\to g is a natural transformation \alpha \colon f_{*}\to g_{*}.
An (elementary) topos is a finitely complete and cartesian closed category equipped with a subobject classifier.
